facts.text: Appellant convicted by Sessions Judge, Patiala, of offence under s.302 IPC for murder of Gurdev Singh and sentenced to death.
Punjab High Court dismissed appellant's appeal (Criminal Appeal No. 890 of 1961) and confirmed death sentence in Murder Reference No. 74 of 1961 on October 25, 1961.
Present appeal by special leave granted by Supreme Court.

Prosecution case: At about 2.30 p.m. on November 18, 1960, Gurdev Singh passing tea-stall of Charan Singh near courts at Barnala on motorcycle; appellant Sewa Singh in shop with double barrel gun stood up and fired shot hitting right side of chest; Gurdev Singh died instantaneously; appellant and Gogar Singh ran away.
Accused pleaded not guilty; disputed that he was the culprit; not disputed that Gurdev Singh died of gunshot injury at time and place alleged.

Occurrence witnessed by Charan Singh (owner, turned hostile, denied knowledge of who fired), Mukhtiar Singh (student), Bakhtawar Singh (having tea in shop); latter two knew appellant from before and testified seeing him fire double barrel gun.
Evidence of Mukhtiar Singh and Bakhtawar Singh believed by Trial Judge and High Court.

Doctor's evidence: Wound roundish 1-1/2 x 1-1/4 communicating with right chest cavity; plugged with cork wadding and cardboard disc of 12 bore cartridge; right fourth and fifth ribs blown off under wound; right lung punctured over 2-1/2 x 2 area; woollen coat bloodstained with corresponding rent blackened charred; shirt bloodstained with corresponding rent blackened. Opinion: Distance 3-4 feet. Deposition from Committing Court used in Sessions under s.509 CrPC; opinion not challenged.

legal_issues.text: Whether features of gunshot injury indicate shot fired from close contact (few inches) contradicting eyewitnesses' version of distance, requiring re-appreciation of eyewitness evidence.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court did not consider injury characteristics; features (roundish wound, wadding plugged, ribs and lung blown off, clothes blackened/charred) show gun held in close contact or within 2-3 inches per Zora Singh case and doctor's evidence; eyewitnesses claimed different distance, so did not witness occurrence.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Zora Singh v. State of Punjab (Criminal Appeal No. 81 of 1957, 10.5.1957)

court_reasoning.text: Wound size (1-1/2 x 1-1/4) indicates shot from about a yard, per forensic texts (Sir Sidney Smith, Major Sir Gerald Burrard, Lyons, Taylor); not contact shot.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Far from supporting contact shot, wound size indicates yard distance.

court_reasoning.text: Blackening/char on clothes not indicative of few inches; possible up to yard or yard and half per Taylor; no blackening/burning on skin.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Burning marks on clothes consistent with yard distance.

court_reasoning.text: Wad lodged in wound consistent with near discharge up to yard per Glaister and Sir Sidney Smith.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Wad entry not limited to few inches.

court_reasoning.text: Blowing off of ribs/lung indicates gas entry (close range) but inconsistent with wound size measurement; prefer wound size over this description; accept doctor's unchallenged opinion of 3-4 feet.

holdings.text: Injury features do not indicate close-range shot; eyewitness evidence reliable; no reason to interfere with High Court's assessment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Zora Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Cited by appellant for close-range shot inference from injury features

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offence of murder for which appellant convicted

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Doctor's deposition from Committing Court treated as evidence in Sessions Court

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; conviction under s.302 IPC and death sentence confirmed; no interference with High Court's assessment of evidence.

key_quotes.text: we have come to the conclusion that the doctors opinion as given in his examination-in-chief, which was not challenged in cross- examination before the Committing Magistrate, that the shot may have been fired about three to four feet away should be accepted as correct.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Court accepts doctor's distance opinion after analysis

key_quotes.text: There is thus some apparent inconsistency between what is indicated by the size of the wound and what the doctor has described as the blowing off of the ribs and a part of the right lung.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Resolves apparent conflict in injury evidence
